body: @csantanapr FYI you may want to review the readme steps.
no pg yet.

@csantanapr I try to install OpenWhisk on my Ubuntu natively. When I'm trying to configure db following the description in tools/db/README.md, I find there is no `local_db.ini` in folder `openwhisk/ansible`. It took me a few minutes to find how to create this file. So I think we should clearly document it in `tools/db/README.md`. If you agree to this change, I will also update `Using Cloudant` section appropriately.
pull 605 is merged, can you pls try again or reproduce the issue?
FYI: @domdom82 @jeremiaswerner

looks good. background - we have different authdbs in blue per environment. now described as "auth_db" (following guideline where _ notation is env specific and . notation is global). To make this look the same in open we have added this PR.

Looks good can you attach the file pizza.xml so I can try it out. 
maybe we can have a short version of this file in the docs this it's easier for an user to give it a quick try

Also please add unit tests we want to have all catalog content tested with Travis CI

Since I've just been through the process of creating my own [feed provider](http://jamesthom.as/blog/2016/06/15/openwhisk-and-mqtt/), here's my feedback... 
- Good section about the architectures, I hadn't thought about using the alarm package to handle polling. I spent most of my time digging through the existing catalogue feeds to understand how they work. Would be useful to include code samples with each of the architecture types to help users see how this works in reality. Either that or link directly to one of the catalogue samples that implements that pattern.
- This section should include the commands needed to registered a feed, I had to find this from the setup scripts.

```
wsk action create -a feed true feed_name feed_action.js
```

@lzbj I added WIP to the title to indicate that this is still in progress and the only left are the test cases for the new action.
Do we need the extra subfolder `dockerSkeleton`?

I agree with @markusthoemmes let's not have an extra folder `dockerSkeleton` source control (github).
I prefer to have it more flat, and aligns better if we move the sdk to it's own repo (i.e. openwhisk-sdk-docker)

I'm ok if the sdk-docker.tar.gz contains an extra folder inside i.e. `openwhisk-sdk-docker`
Looks signed-off to me, unless @lehoanganh objects?

Merged as 32fcd87aa0e0b0ac49c79d1940cc219bdaa24df4 . The documentation is essentially in the commit message now, should we duplicate to somewhere? Or should we not, since it's "just sugar" and documenting means running the risk of getting out of sync?
Put the commit message into the tool user can run `redo` or just `redo help` and let the tool print the usage which essentially the commit message
FWIW `redo -h` already offers a useful guide. Not as verbose as the commit message, though (sort of like `tool --help` vs `man tool`).
Tests look good to me. Will wait for PG build. We should as usual be careful and make sure the Docker image is available on all testing machines if running a distributed build. (cf. #657)

> FWIW redo -h already offers a useful guide. Not as verbose as the commit message, though (sort of like tool --help vs man tool).

What's your proposal `redo man` or `redo.md` ?

I'd say `tools/build/README.md`. Do we still have a PR exemption for
documentation edits?

@lehoanganh @domdom82 FYI
Are the concerns under separable? That requires systematically addressing all the packages since none have these. Whereas 1-2 strike me as in scope.

The godep tool is useful for taking a snapshot of the dependencies and associated git hash.  This information is stored in a godep json file and is then used to restore the exact versions of these dependencies.  Actual snapshot of the source of the dependencies could be save in the repo, but at the moment, I think the json file is sufficient. 
https://github.com/tools/godep
I'll be issuing a PR for this build update

IPG 84
LGTM, thanks for creating.

@tuler FYI we have the policy of a linear git-history, meaning: no merge commits. Your pull-request reminded me that we haven't documented that, which we have now, see https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/wiki/Contributing:-Git-guidelines.

You don't need to mind for this pull-request, we will just squash on merge, but for future pull-request it'll be easier for us if `rebase` is used to keep the pull-request on track instead of `merge`.

Good point.

@csantanapr - This issue is ready for closure.  Since you are the issue originator, you can either close it or give your up vote and I'll close it based on your acceptance.  Thanks!

I set couchdb param like this
1. vagrant up
2. vagrant ssh
3. in the virtual env,  execute:

export OW_DB=CouchDB
export OW_DB_USERNAME=admin
export OW_DB_PASSWORD=86889125
export OW_DB_PROTOCOL=http
export OW_DB_HOST=172.17.0.2
export OW_DB_PORT=6000

ansible-playbook setup.yml
1. execute

cd openwhisk_home
gradle distDocker
cd ansible
ansible-playbook -i environments/local couchdb.yml
ansible-playbook -i environments/local initdb.yml   -> where error comes from
Is there anything wrong with my param setting?
If it's a local deployment, the cli is already on disk (openwhisk/bin) isn't it?
You can also download the CLI from your own local deployment, and install from there. Should be the same process, but not using bluemix at all.
the issue can be reproduced on Ephemeral CouchDB case
@csantanapr looks like the Visual Recognition V3 appears after 1.8.0 so I'd say no.

Downloading the CLI from the OW API endpoint was broken, there is an issue open but I have not checked personally to see if it's fix now.

The same goes for downloading the docker and mobile sdk using the CLI, there were issues open for this
Good to know thanks for checking.
What exactly is the issue you experience?

I'll update the build to create a wsk.exe.zip for each Windows binary, a wks.zip (if that's the Mac custom) for each Mac wsk binary, and a wsk.tar.gz for each Linux wsk binary.  These files will be in addition to the uncompressed files and will be located in the same build output folder as each uncompressed counterpart.
tar.gz will work for mac also.
ok.  mac binaries will be compress to .tar.gz
@dubeejw - Would you kindly review the GO CLI build.xml changes.  Thanks!
Prettier, based on feedback. IPG 101 eventually.
Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/386a45110c7eed940056471a03ad9b8640b8a9f4.
Vincent @houshengbo - You will probably want to use the compressed Go binary files as the downloadable binaries.
@csantanapr - Is this a duplicate of #577 or is there some additional subtlety this issue is covering?
@mdeuser can you rebase and squash into a single commit please?
LGTM to me I will wait for @dubeejw to signed off with a ðŸ‘
This one is duplicate of #577 I will close this one.

fatal: [localhost -> localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": "\"docker-
achine\" \"ip\" \"whisk\"", "delta": "0:00:00.003987", "end": "2016-06-16 10:42
19.515486", "failed": true, "rc": 127, "start": "2016-06-16 10:42:19.511499", "
tderr": "/bin/sh: 1: docker-machine: not found", "stdout": "", "stdout_lines":
], "warnings": []}
...ignoring

not sure this means the command failed to execute sth?
@mdeuser, you may want to sync up with Vincent as he is zipping the binaries when publishing them to nginx.
@houshengbo, are you compressing the binaries when publishing to nginx?

@mdeuser, @houshengbo, please refer to openwhisk/ansible/roles/cli/tasks/deploy.yml to see how Ansible compresses, and publishes the Python CLI. I'm not sure we want to support deploying the binaries with Ant as well.
@mdeuser, @houshengbo, with Ansible we can tar the binaries in the Docker container then publish the binaries to nginx.

For comments.  Both CF and Bluemix name their CLI binary downloads with additional identification labeling.  Such as `Bluemix_CLI_0.3.3_amd64`, `cf-cli_6.19.0_winx64.zip`, `cf-cli_6.19.0_linux_i686.tgz`

Probably something for us to consider.  We can handle the platform/architecture bits right now (if agreed), but will need some OpenWhisk wide version value (may be there and I just don't know about it) to add the version number.

/cc @csantanapr @houshengbo
@dubeejw - I did try to compress within Docker (no ansible), but the zip command was not available in the docker image, so I had to move the compression into the build scripts.

@mdeuser, I see now. It looks like the Python CLI is compressed during the Gradle build via the distTar task. I had to convert the Go CLI build from Ansible to Gradle as there were numerous issues trying to get Jenkins to build the CLI with Ansible. @csantanapr , the build.xml looks file. :+1:  We should include the compression routine in the new Gradle build script though.

I think it will be good to have granular download os+arch
About the CLI version, today the CLI has a version and it's the build id timestamp

**whisk CLI version 2016-06-09T16:31:10Z**

You get the version from today using `wsk property get` check with @dubeejw where is this value

I think since we should try to keep the url constant across builds, that way people, the UI, the url doesn't change to download it from the nginx proxy `https://$apihost/cli/go/download/mac/amd64/wsk_mac_amd64.tgz`

In addition user can use a web browser and go to `https://$apihost/cli/go/download/mac/` and navigate the directory structure

@rabbah what do you think?

```
$ wsk property get
whisk auth      23bc46b1-...
whisk API host      192.168.99.102
whisk API version   v1
whisk namespace     _
whisk CLI version   2016-06-09T16:31:10Z
```

Check @domdom82 with about Ansible problems, if doing with Gradle need to check how to do zip (for windows) in addition of tgz (mac, linux).

So let's not do it with ant, and just do it with final solution, let's not waist more effort on ant

Perhaps for another issue, but the CLI version being a timestamp does not seem right to me.  There's a version in the python CLI download file, `openwhisk-0.1.0.tar.gz`, that does not match the `whisk CLI version` property value.  Perhaps what we currently have is more like a "CLI build" - similar to the `whisk API build` property for the API.
@mdeuser So we are in agreement to not include any build id in to the name of the binary and be just os+arch `wsk_mac_amd64.tgz` `wsk_windows_amd64.zip` `wsk_linux_i386.tgz` etc...
@csantanapr, there are distTar, and distZip tasks. The distZip should cover the compressed binaries for Windows.
Using Gradle to build the CLI is nice because you can hotswap Gradle to just build the CLI: gradle :tools:go-cli:distDocker.
Great so let's do both using gradle then
rebased.
PG 104 approved.
@csantanapr - commits are squashed.
